name: Zen Koans Oracle
description: 36 classic Zen koans paired with traditional East Asian ink paintings. Koans are paradoxical riddles used in Zen Buddhism to provoke enlightenment by short-circuiting logical thinking. Each card invites contemplation beyond ordinary mind.

attribution.note: Koans compiled from traditional sources. Artwork from public domain collections.

items.name: Mu (The Gateless Gate)

sections.Koan: A monk asked Zhaozhou: 'Does a dog have Buddha-nature?' Zhaozhou replied: 'Mu.' (No/Nothing)
sections.Interpretation: This is the most famous koan, given to beginners. 'Mu' is not yes or no—it cuts through the question itself. What assumption are you making that the universe refuses to confirm or deny?
sections.Reversed: Trapped in binary thinking. Seeking answers where none exist. The question itself may be the problem.

questions: What question are you asking that has no answer?
What would remain if you stopped seeking?

items.name: The Sound of One Hand

sections.Koan: You know the sound of two hands clapping. What is the sound of one hand?
sections.Interpretation: Hakuin's famous koan points to what exists before duality. Before comparison, before relationship, before 'this and that'—what is there? Listen for what cannot be heard.
sections.Reversed: Overthinking the unanswerable. Trying to logic your way to insight. Sometimes the mind must exhaust itself.

questions: What exists before comparison?
What do you know without thinking?

items.name: Original Face

sections.Koan: What was your original face before your parents were born?
sections.Interpretation: Before conditioning, culture, name, and story—what are you? This koan points to the unconditioned awareness that witnesses all experience. You existed before your biography.
sections.Reversed: Identified with roles and stories. Forgetting the awareness beneath personality. Who would you be without your history?

questions: What remains constant through all your changes?
Who is aware of your thoughts?

items.name: Wash Your Bowl

sections.Koan: A monk said to Zhaozhou: 'I have just entered the monastery. Please teach me.' Zhaozhou asked: 'Have you eaten your rice porridge?' The monk replied: 'I have eaten.' Zhaozhou said: 'Then go wash your bowl.'
sections.Interpretation: Enlightenment is not separate from ordinary activity. The profound teaching is: do the next thing completely. Seeking special wisdom while neglecting what's in front of you misses the point entirely.
sections.Reversed: Seeking the extraordinary while ignoring the ordinary. Spiritual bypassing. The sacred is hidden in the mundane.

questions: What simple task are you avoiding?
Can you find enlightenment in washing dishes?

items.name: Kill the Buddha

sections.Koan: If you meet the Buddha on the road, kill him.
sections.Interpretation: Any fixed image of enlightenment becomes an obstacle. The Buddha you can conceptualize is not the living truth. This koan warns against idolatry of teachers, teachings, or even awakening itself.
sections.Reversed: Clinging to spiritual concepts. Making enlightenment into another possession. The finger pointing at the moon is not the moon.

questions: What spiritual concept are you clinging to?
What would you lose if you stopped seeking?

items.name: A Cup of Tea

sections.Koan: Nan-in served tea to a professor. He poured until the cup overflowed and kept pouring. The professor cried: 'It is overfull! No more will go in!' Nan-in replied: 'Like this cup, you are full of your own opinions. How can I show you Zen unless you first empty your cup?'
sections.Interpretation: Learning requires emptiness. When full of certainty, no new understanding can enter. Beginner's mind is expert's mind—approach everything as if for the first time.
sections.Reversed: Knowing too much. Opinions blocking experience. Pride in knowledge prevents wisdom.

questions: What are you too certain about?
Where might emptiness create space for insight?

items.name: Muddy Road

sections.Koan: Tanzan and Ekido were walking. They met a lovely girl in a silk kimono unable to cross the muddy intersection. Tanzan lifted her and carried her across. That evening Ekido said: 'We monks don't go near females. Why did you do that?' Tanzan replied: 'I left the girl there. Are you still carrying her?'
sections.Interpretation: The mind that clings to rules often violates their spirit. Who is more attached—the one who helped and moved on, or the one who judged and couldn't let go? Carrying mental burdens is heavier than carrying people.
sections.Reversed: Holding onto past events. Judging others while carrying your own weight. The burden is in the carrying, not the doing.

questions: What are you still carrying from the past?
Who do you judge for having moved on?

items.name: The Moon Cannot Be Stolen

sections.Koan: Ryokan lived simply in a hut. One night a thief visited but found nothing to steal. Ryokan returned and said: 'You may have come a long way. Please take my clothes as a gift.' The thief left bewildered. Ryokan sat naked, watching the moon: 'Poor fellow, I wish I could give him this beautiful moon.'
sections.Interpretation: True wealth cannot be taken. What you really possess—awareness, presence, beauty—is beyond theft. The one who has nothing to lose has everything.
sections.Reversed: Identifying with possessions. Fear of loss. What you cling to owns you.

questions: What do you have that cannot be stolen?
What would remain if you lost everything?

items.name: Is That So?

sections.Koan: A girl's parents accused Hakuin of fathering her child. 'Is that so?' he said, and took the baby. Later, they confessed another man was the father and came to take the baby back. 'Is that so?' Hakuin said, and returned the child.
sections.Interpretation: Equanimity in praise and blame alike. Hakuin's reputation was destroyed and restored, but his response remained unchanged. Freedom is not minding what happens.
sections.Reversed: Defending reputation. Attached to how others see you. Your peace depends on what they think.

questions: How much energy do you spend managing others' opinions?
Can you accept both praise and blame equally?

items.name: The Oak Tree in the Garden

sections.Koan: A monk asked Zhaozhou: 'What is the meaning of Bodhidharma's coming from the West?' Zhaozhou replied: 'The oak tree in the garden.'
sections.Interpretation: The profound teaching is right in front of you—that tree, this breath, whatever is present. Seeking meaning elsewhere misses the point. The entire teaching is in this moment's reality.
sections.Reversed: Looking for meaning in philosophy while ignoring reality. The answer is always closer than your thoughts.

questions: What is right in front of you that you're overlooking?
Where are you seeking answers that are already present?

items.name: Hyakujo's Fox

sections.Koan: An old man told Hyakujo: 'I was a Zen master. A student asked if an enlightened person is subject to cause and effect. I said: No. For 500 lives I've been reborn as a fox. Please say a turning word.' Hyakujo said: 'An enlightened person does not ignore cause and effect.'
sections.Interpretation: Awakening doesn't exempt you from consequences. Spiritual bypassing—using enlightenment to escape karma—traps you further. Freedom is through reality, not around it.
sections.Reversed: Using spirituality to avoid responsibility. Thinking awakening means no consequences. Every action still ripples.

questions: Where are you avoiding consequences?
What responsibility are you spiritualizing away?

items.name: Not Mind, Not Buddha

sections.Koan: A monk asked Mazu: 'What is Buddha?' Mazu said: 'Mind is Buddha.' Later another monk asked the same. Mazu said: 'Not mind, not Buddha.'
sections.Interpretation: The teaching changes because you change. What liberates today becomes a cage tomorrow. Mazu's contradiction points to truth beyond formulas. Don't cling even to correct answers.
sections.Reversed: Collecting spiritual truths. Turning living teaching into dead doctrine. What freed you may now bind you.

questions: What spiritual truth have you turned into a cage?
Can you hold teachings lightly?

items.name: The Moving Mind

sections.Koan: Two monks argued about a flag waving. One said: 'The flag is moving.' The other said: 'The wind is moving.' The Sixth Patriarch said: 'Neither flag nor wind is moving. Mind is moving.'
sections.Interpretation: All perception is interpretation. The movement you see 'out there' reflects movement in here. When mind is still, even chaos appears peaceful. The world mirrors your state.
sections.Reversed: Blaming external circumstances. Waiting for the world to settle down. Your agitation colors everything.

questions: What turbulence are you projecting onto the world?
If your mind were still, what would change?

items.name: Three Pounds of Flax

sections.Koan: A monk asked Dongshan: 'What is Buddha?' Dongshan said: 'Three pounds of flax.'
sections.Interpretation: Buddha is not an abstraction but this very reality—the weight of flax, the texture of cloth, whatever is at hand. The sacred is not separate from the material world.
sections.Reversed: Seeking the spiritual separate from the physical. Missing enlightenment in ordinary objects. The sacred hides in plain sight.

questions: What ordinary thing might be showing you Buddha?
Where do you separate spiritual from material?

items.name: Gutei's Finger

sections.Koan: Gutei raised his finger whenever asked about Zen. A boy began imitating him. Gutei cut off the boy's finger. As the boy ran away screaming, Gutei called him. When the boy turned, Gutei raised his finger. The boy was enlightened.
sections.Interpretation: Imitation without understanding is not Zen. The boy copied the form without the substance. Gutei's severe compassion destroyed the false to reveal the real. What gestures do you copy without comprehending?
sections.Reversed: Spiritual imitation. Copying teachers' mannerisms instead of their understanding. The pointing finger is not the moon.

questions: What are you imitating without understanding?
Where is the form hiding the emptiness?

items.name: Kyogen's Man in a Tree

sections.Koan: Kyogen said: 'A man hangs from a tree by his teeth. His hands cannot grasp a branch, his feet cannot touch the tree. Someone below asks: What is Zen? If he opens his mouth, he falls and dies. If he doesn't answer, he fails the questioner. What should he do?'
sections.Interpretation: Some situations have no safe answer. Life sometimes demands we risk everything to speak our truth—or remain silent and fail another. This is the crucible of authentic existence.
sections.Reversed: Seeking safety in every situation. Refusing to risk. Sometimes there is no right answer, only authentic response.

questions: Where are you hanging, afraid to speak or stay silent?
What truth might cost you everything?

items.name: Zuigan Calls His Master

sections.Koan: Zuigan Gen would call to himself every day: 'Master!' and answer: 'Yes, sir!' Then he would say: 'Be wide awake!' and answer: 'Yes, sir!' 'From now on, don't be fooled by others!' 'No, I won't!'
sections.Interpretation: Self-inquiry as practice. Zuigan reminded himself daily to stay present and not be deceived by conditioning. Who is it that answers when you call? This practice reveals the witness.
sections.Reversed: Living on autopilot. Forgetting to question who is thinking, feeling, acting. Asleep to your own awareness.

questions: Who answers when you call yourself?
How do you wake yourself up?

items.name: Joshu's Stone Bridge

sections.Koan: A monk said to Joshu: 'I have heard of the famous stone bridge of Joshu, but I see only a simple log bridge.' Joshu said: 'You see only the log bridge. You don't see the stone bridge.' The monk asked: 'What is the stone bridge?' Joshu said: 'Donkeys cross over, horses cross over.'
sections.Interpretation: The famous bridge is not spectacular—it simply lets all beings cross. True greatness serves without ostentation. The magnificent functions ordinarily.
sections.Reversed: Looking for the flashy teaching while missing the functional one. Expecting enlightenment to look special.

questions: What simple bridge are you overlooking?
Where do you expect greatness to be flashy?

items.name: Nansen Cuts the Cat

sections.Koan: Monks of the Eastern and Western halls were arguing about a cat. Nansen held up the cat and said: 'If you can say a word of Zen, I will spare the cat. If not, I will kill it.' No one spoke. Nansen cut the cat. Later, Joshu returned. Nansen told him. Joshu put his sandals on his head and walked out. Nansen said: 'If you had been there, you could have saved the cat.'
sections.Interpretation: Words fail in the face of life and death. Joshu's absurd response broke the frame—he didn't argue, explain, or freeze. In crisis, fresh action trumps rehearsed wisdom.
sections.Reversed: Paralyzed by the need for correct response. Letting life pass while you figure out the right answer.

questions: What situation paralyzes you with the need for the 'right' response?
When did absurdity save you?

items.name: Ordinary Mind is the Way

sections.Koan: Joshu asked Nansen: 'What is the Way?' Nansen said: 'Ordinary mind is the Way.' Joshu asked: 'Should I try to direct myself toward it?' Nansen said: 'If you try to direct yourself, you turn away from it.'
sections.Interpretation: The Way is not extraordinary. It's this—breathing, walking, sitting, the ordinary flow of life. Seeking makes it distant. Trying to find it proves you've overlooked it.
sections.Reversed: Making enlightenment into an achievement. Striving away from what's already here. You cannot try your way to effortlessness.

questions: How is your seeking keeping you from finding?
What if you're already on the Way?

items.name: The Buffalo Passes Through

sections.Koan: Goso said: 'A buffalo passes through the window. Its head, horns, and four legs pass through. Why can't its tail pass through?'
sections.Interpretation: Almost free, but one small attachment remains. The great work is nearly done but something still binds. What tiny thing keeps you from complete liberation?
sections.Reversed: Thinking you're free while subtly bound. The final attachment is often the hardest to see.

questions: What tail of attachment still holds you?
What do you think you've released but haven't?

items.name: The Gateless Gate

sections.Koan: The Great Way has no gate. A thousand roads enter it. When you pass through this gateless gate, you walk the universe alone.
sections.Interpretation: There is no special entrance to awakening—everywhere is the door. Yet passing through requires you alone. No one can walk this for you. The gateless gate is everywhere and nowhere.
sections.Reversed: Looking for the special entrance. Waiting for permission. The gate you seek is your own resistance.

questions: What gate are you looking for that doesn't exist?
What if everywhere is the entrance?

items.name: No Self, No Problem

sections.Koan: Bodhidharma sat facing a wall. The Second Patriarch stood in the snow and cut off his arm to show his sincerity. He said: 'My mind is not at peace. Please pacify it.' Bodhidharma said: 'Bring me your mind and I will pacify it.' The Patriarch said: 'I have searched for my mind but cannot find it.' Bodhidharma said: 'Then I have pacified it.'
sections.Interpretation: The troubled mind cannot be found when looked for directly. What cannot be located cannot be a problem. The search itself reveals the emptiness of what was sought.
sections.Reversed: Treating the mind as a solid thing to be fixed. Looking for peace through problem-solving. Sometimes the solution is seeing there's no problem.

questions: Can you find your troubled mind when you look directly?
What problem dissolves when examined closely?

items.name: The Stone Woman Gives Birth

sections.Koan: Nangaku asked: 'Where do you come from?' Shitou said: 'From Caoxi.' Nangaku said: 'What did you get at Caoxi?' Shitou said: 'Even before going to Caoxi, nothing was lacking.' Nangaku said: 'Then why did you go?' Shitou said: 'If I had not gone, how could I know that nothing was lacking?'
sections.Interpretation: The journey reveals what was always true. You seek to discover you were never lost. The paradox of spiritual practice: working to realize no work was needed, going to arrive where you started.
sections.Reversed: Thinking the journey is pointless because the destination is here. Or thinking arrival negates the path. Both the seeking and the finding are needed.

questions: What journey revealed what you already had?
What do you need to seek in order to stop seeking?

items.name: The Fire God Seeks Fire

sections.Koan: Fayan asked: 'Where are you going?' Dizang said: 'On pilgrimage.' Fayan asked: 'What is the purpose of pilgrimage?' Dizang said: 'I don't know.' Fayan said: 'Not knowing is nearest.'
sections.Interpretation: The honest answer is 'I don't know.' The fire god searching for fire is absurd, yet we do this constantly—seeking what we already are. Not knowing opens the gateless gate.
sections.Reversed: Pretending to know. Covering confusion with concepts. 'I don't know' is both the question and the answer.

questions: Where are you the fire god seeking fire?
What do you pretend to know?

items.name: Drop It

sections.Koan: A student said: 'I have nothing.' Jingqing said: 'Then drop it.' The student said: 'I have nothing. What can I drop?' Jingqing said: 'Then carry it out.'
sections.Interpretation: Even 'nothing' becomes a something when held. The subtle pride in emptiness is still attachment. If you cannot drop your 'nothing,' it owns you. True emptiness doesn't announce itself.
sections.Reversed: Spiritual pride in having let go. Attachment to non-attachment. The emptiness that proclaims itself is not empty.

questions: What 'nothing' are you carrying?
Can you drop even your letting go?

items.name: Dried Shit Stick

sections.Koan: A monk asked Yunmen: 'What is Buddha?' Yunmen said: 'A dried shit stick.'
sections.Interpretation: Even the most elevated question receives the most humble answer. Buddha is not separate from the basest reality. This shocking response destroys the questioner's precious images.
sections.Reversed: Elevating spirituality above the mundane. Making Buddha too pure for reality. The sacred is everywhere or nowhere.

questions: What spiritual concept needs its pedestal kicked?
Where do you make the sacred too clean?

items.name: Buddha Holds Up a Flower

sections.Koan: The World-Honored One held up a flower. Mahakashyapa smiled. The World-Honored One said: 'I have the treasury of the true dharma eye, the subtle mind of nirvana. I transmit it to Mahakashyapa.'
sections.Interpretation: The deepest teaching is wordless. A flower held, a smile exchanged—complete transmission outside scripture. What cannot be said can still be shared, presence to presence.
sections.Reversed: Expecting wisdom to be verbal. Missing non-conceptual transmission. The teaching is not always in the words.

questions: What teaching came to you without words?
Who has understood you without explanation?

items.name: The Cypress Tree in the Garden

sections.Koan: A monk asked Joshu: 'What is the meaning of Bodhidharma's coming from the West?' Joshu said: 'The cypress tree in the garden.'
sections.Interpretation: A different day, a different tree—Joshu's answer changes but the pointing remains. The meaning of the teaching is this, here, now. Not philosophy but reality.
sections.Reversed: Collecting answers instead of seeing what they point to. The cypress tree is not a symbol—it's a cypress tree.

questions: What is right in front of you that is the answer?
When do you collect symbols instead of seeing?

items.name: Good Snow

sections.Koan: Pang Yun said to Layman Pang: 'Good snow. Flake after flake falls, each in its place.' A scholar asked: 'Where do they fall?' Pang slapped him.
sections.Interpretation: Each thing falls perfectly into its place in the great pattern. To ask 'where?' intellectually misses the point. The slap returns the scholar to direct experience. Can you see without asking?
sections.Reversed: Analyzing instead of experiencing. Turning presence into philosophy. Some questions deserve a slap.

questions: Can you see the snow without asking where it falls?
What question interrupts your direct experience?

items.name: When Hungry, Eat

sections.Koan: A monk asked: 'What is the Way?' The master said: 'When hungry, eat; when tired, sleep.' The monk said: 'That's what everyone does.' The master said: 'When they eat, they do not just eat—they think of a thousand things. When they sleep, they do not just sleep—they dream of a thousand things.'
sections.Interpretation: The Way is simplicity itself, but we complicate it. When eating, just eat. When sleeping, just sleep. Total presence in ordinary activities is extraordinary—this is the entire teaching.
sections.Reversed: Never fully present. Mind always elsewhere. Even simple acts become fragmented by thinking.

questions: When did you last just eat?
Where does your mind go instead of being here?

items.name: Carry the Stick

sections.Koan: Sekkyo said: 'If you have a staff, I will give you one. If you have no staff, I will take it away.'
sections.Interpretation: Those who have receive more; those who lack lose even that. This sounds cruel but points to a truth: approach from abundance and abundance grows. Approach from lack and lack deepens.
sections.Reversed: Waiting to receive before you have. Spiritual neediness. Sometimes you must give what you want to receive.

questions: What do you approach from lack that you could approach from abundance?
What do you need to give in order to receive?

items.name: The One Road

sections.Koan: Ummon said: 'The world is vast and wide. Why do you put on your robe at the sound of the bell?'
sections.Interpretation: With infinite freedom, why follow the form? The koan challenges us to see that choosing structure is itself freedom. The vast world and the narrow way are not opposed.
sections.Reversed: Seeing form and freedom as opposites. Rejecting structure in the name of liberation. Or clinging to form and forgetting freedom.

questions: Why do you follow the forms you follow?
How is your discipline an expression of freedom?

items.name: Not by Sitting

sections.Koan: Nanyue saw Mazu sitting in meditation. He asked: 'What are you doing?' Mazu said: 'Sitting in meditation to become Buddha.' Nanyue picked up a tile and began polishing it. Mazu asked: 'What are you doing?' Nanyue said: 'Making a mirror.' Mazu said: 'How can polishing a tile make a mirror?' Nanyue said: 'How can sitting in meditation make a Buddha?'
sections.Interpretation: Practice cannot manufacture enlightenment. A tile cannot become a mirror no matter how much you polish. Yet we still sit. The sitting is not the cause—it's the expression.
sections.Reversed: Thinking more practice equals more enlightenment. Mechanical sitting. The doing doesn't create the being.

questions: What are you polishing that can never become what you want?
Is your practice causing awakening or expressing it?

items.name: Before Donkey, After Horse

sections.Koan: Sushan said: 'If the front of the donkey has not yet gone, the back of the horse has already arrived.'
sections.Interpretation: Beginning and ending overlap. Before one thing finishes, another has begun. Time is not linear but layered. This moment contains past and future without being bound by them.
sections.Reversed: Living in sequences. Waiting for endings before beginnings. Life is more simultaneous than serial.

questions: What is arriving before the previous thing has left?
How does this moment contain all moments?

items.name: Return to the Marketplace

sections.Koan: Entering the marketplace with open hands, barefoot and unadorned, face smeared with earth, head covered with ashes—a huge laugh bursts forth. Without the need for the miraculous power of gods, you make the withered tree bloom.
sections.Interpretation: The final stage: returning to ordinary life after awakening. Not transcending the world but embracing it completely. The sage is indistinguishable from the fool, yet withered trees bloom in their presence.
sections.Reversed: Staying on the mountain. Spiritual isolation. True awakening returns you to the marketplace.

questions: How do you bring your insights back to ordinary life?
What withered tree awaits your attention?
